fields.headline: Boudu Saved From Drowning
fields.bodyText: Jean Renoir's Boudu Saved From Drowning, made in 1932 and remade not at all badly in 1986 by Paul Mazursky as Down and Out in Beverly Hills, is getting released in cinemas around the country and being shown at the NFT throughout January as part of a major Renoir retrospective and is an extremely bold satire on bourgeois values. Essentially a comic paean to anarchism, it stars the great Michel Simon, France's answer to Charles Laughton, as a Parisian tramp who's rescued from suicide by a kindly, middle-aged bookseller. But instead of showing a proper gratitude to his saviour and benefactor, the unrepentant clochard sets about seducing his host's wife and creating maximum disorder in his cosy household. Boudu is a deceptively rough-looking black-and-white film with long takes and sound recorded on location.
